title: I GOT A PERMANENT BAN
body:
I have not been on league of legends for a while now, when i logged onto league there was a permanent ban on my account.

One of my good friends who i use to talk to a lot shared this account, it was my account, my email and stuff, this person had betrayed me a few weeks ago, and  been trying to scam most of my items in games such as runescape, csgo and rakion.
i can only assume that he flamed/cursed a lot on my account to give me a permanent ban on purpose.
i had forgotten to change my league of legends password when he betrayed my trust.

Waiting for your reply.

replies.body:
Hey there,

Sorry to hear your account was banned, unfortunately my guess would be you were banned for account sharing and not because your friend went on to be toxic, although this could have contributed to the ban.

Account sharing is against the EULA/ToS for league of legends.

Call the ACCC.
Queensland laws maybe different in your area. In Queensland we have a law called " Life of purchase " meaning if you spent money on your account. You paid money with a idea of how long you will have access to that item and so on.

Check the laws and contact the support with the law and actions you want to happen. If they do not do as requested you have the right to take it even higher by contacting the ombudsman.

After that you can take it even higher by contacting the minister for ACCC to have the issue resolved. After which you should contact a lawyer about legal rights you have and and so on. 

Hope this helps. Remember if you live in Aus. ACCC PROTECTS YOU FROM STUFF LIKE THIS!

P.S

EULA/ToS

Can be by passed by the feeling of paying money for a item. Meaning you will always agree to them because you have invested money into it.

P.SS

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H1a1ojlgyJQ&index=2&list=PLm9MoTQ-chADxF9-jt-2N38wDrirNdv03

Played list for ACCC laws. These are BASIC IDEAS. You should google for more information in detail

To the best of my understanding, the Life of Purchase Law would only apply if you were unaware of the conditions. The whole idea is that you have a general idea of how long that thing will last when you spend money on it, and by accepting the ToS/EULA you have stated that you understand that if you break the Code of Conduct you will be banned. Thus the "Life of Purchase" is only a lifetime so long as you do not break the code of conduct. By breaking the CoC you have essentially ended the Life of Purchase.

It's like if you know something is dry clean only, but choose to put it in the washing machine anyway. It was labelled, and you were fully aware it was dry clean only, so the only one responsible for the item's 'death' is you. Sure it might be fine, but if it's not you aren't going to get a replacement or refund for it.

This being an account sharing thing is a bit more of an ambiguous case, but I'll think you'll find that Riot hasn't done anything outside their rights here.

> Same can be applied to Undue Influence.

With the exceptions of professional play and streamers/content creators, League of Legends is not a profession. You do not earn money for it, it is not your livelihood. If your main source of income was directly linked to the game then you might get away with something like that. 

But your case is ambiguous anyway. Microsoft Office has terms and conditions you must agree too on installation, so does Windows, OSX, and about a zillion other things that people NEED for their jobs. It isn't undue influence because there are alternatives. It would only be undue influence if there was no alternative. The alternatives to LoL are any other game that exists, or if you want to get more specific games like DOTA2 and Smite. 

Perhaps it helps to think of it differently. LoL is the game yes, but Riot is a service provider. Think of it like a physical store, and we are the customers. For as long as we are in the store they have a responsibility to us. But if someone comes into the store and starts telling everyone to kill themselves they're gonna get kicked out and banned from the store, and the store is well within their rights to do so. That person could have spent $2000 in the store and it won't make a lick of difference.

As I said before, this is an ambiguous case because of the account sharing thing, but again he's responsible for all activity on his account.

Okay. I understand what you are trying to say. The idea of the programmer was just a point of reference. 

The ToS and so on become pointless once the need out weights the rational thinking. So with this in mind.
They will always click Yes no matter what due to the financial investment they have made. So this will fall under Undue Influence and Duress. 
Since both imply a pending doom for a out come. The customer will feel the need to retain some kind of control. 

Please do not get me wrong here. What happen on his/her account and so on. That is on him / her.

But the facts still stand. 

Once a investment has been made. The time of that investment is to be up held. I buy a skin today to customize my champion that I play. I expect the availability of this skin to be available until either I choose never to play this game again or the company Riot has chosen to close the game servers down for ever.

Once this is not met... I am left with the idea of not having service delivered to me by the company and/or the sellers of the item { in this case. Customized skin for my champion }
So at this point. 

They have fallen in breach of  
" Non-delivery of products & services "  
" Misleading claims & advertising " 
" Consumer guarantees "
" Compensation for damages & loss "
" Repair, replace, refund "
" Consumer protection "
" Warranties "
" 'No refund' signs and expired warranties "

Just to name a few. The bylaws that can be found once looking further into them. Will allow anyone to say " I clicked Yes to ToS and EuA because I have invested a lot of time and money into this "

I am not a lawyer. I am not claiming to be one. I am just someone that has gone down this road with bigger companies than Riot. 
This is why I know you can go down this path way.


But as I said before I will say again.

Call your local member, Call the Ombudsman, Call the ACCC and contact a lawyer. It is a lot easier then you think. 
People that live in AUSTRALIA have rights. Companies like to try and make you forget it.

I'm gonna stick to responding to this I think, since I'm obviously not going to change your mind, but I just wanted to mention something about this. As I mentioned [HERE](http://boards.oce.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behaviour/dcWlims8-riot-please-tell-me-if-my-reports-are-doing-anything?comment=000100000000000000000001). Your account is a lease, you do not own it, you only 'pay' to use it (or simply agree to the terms for free use if you don't buy any RP). 

Therefore the 'time of that investment' is as long as the initial agreement OR upon breaking the agreement however long the lessor deems fit. It's the same as renting a house, you might have an agreement for 6 months, but if you do something to break the terms the rental agency or the owner has the right to kick you out.

My ban was for flaming and it wasn't me, its kind of being hacked, i just forgot to change my password.

Account share and so on.
This is a grey area. Like if I rent a blu ray. Everyone in the house watches it. This is a public viewing.
But it was on a private location and not open to the public so meaning it was a private viewing. 

Same thing  looked at it from 2 views. Email riot. Contact your local member { That is what they are there for } Contact Ombudsman then contact ACCC.

The thing about account sharing leads into the "you are responsible for any action taken on your account". If the account is stolen it's a bit different, and there's a recovery process for that, but if it's just straight account sharing then the responsibility falls to you to know what is happening on your account.

Yes people account share, they won't really be punished so long as it's harmless, but what it comes down to here, is that your account (even if not you) was accused and found guilty of whatever it was and thus has been punished for it.

You wouldn't receive a perma ban for one instance of toxicity unless it is incredibly severe (hate speech kinda deal) so I'm not sure if that would have been why. The email informing you of the ban would have told you what it was for. You can link it here if you want us to look at it, but the chances of the ban being reversed are pretty much 0 for you right now.

Yes Riot's ToS and EULA can't overwrite your consumer rights, but virtual goods have a huge grey cloud over them. 
I'd just make a new account and learn my lesson.
My account was banned for flaming, and this person rarely played my account and never boosted me
Even so, you were still violating the EULA/ToS by account sharing in the first place.
